elements.content: Three new inorganic–organic hybrid frameworks, [Mn2(BPTCA)(phen)2·H2O] n (1), [Mn4(BPTCA)2(H2O)10·2.5H2O] n (2), and [Mn2(BPTCA)(μ2-H2O)2] n (3) (BPTCA4− = 4,4′-bipyridine-2,2′,6,6′-tetracarboxylate; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 is a two-dimensional (2D) network constructed by infinite O−Mn−O−C−O−Mn- chains and BPTCA4− ligands, and an intriguing slide fastener-like three-dimensional (3D) framework structure is formed by the π···π interactions between the phen molecules. Complex 2 crystallized in a chiral space group P21 has a 2D network structure formed by Mn4 cluster units and BPTCA4− linkers, while complex 3 obtained at higher temperature than 2 is a 3D porous architecture. The result implies that the hydrothermal reaction temperature has a great influence on the structure of the complexes in this system. The magnetic behaviors of the complexes have been investigated and 2 showed modest powder second harmonic generation activity.
elements.clean_text: Three new inorganic-organic hybrid frameworks, [Mn2(BPTCA)(phen)2⋅H2O] n  (1), [Mn4(BPTCA)2(H2O)10⋅2.5H2O] n  (2), and [Mn2(BPTCA)(μ2-H2O)2] n  (3) (BPTCA4- = 4,4'-bipyridine-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylate; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 is a two-dimensional (2D) network constructed by infinite O-Mn-O-C-O-Mn- chains and BPTCA4- ligands, and an intriguing slide fastener-like three-dimensional (3D) framework structure is formed by the π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the phen molecules. Complex 2 crystallized in a chiral space group P21 has a 2D network structure formed by Mn4 cluster units and BPTCA4- linkers, while complex 3 obtained at higher temperature than 2 is a 3D porous architecture. The result implies that the hydrothermal reaction temperature has a great influence on the structure of the complexes in this system. The magnetic behaviors of the complexes have been investigated and 2 showed modest powder second harmonic generation activity.

elements.content: The study provides a nice example that the hydrothermal reaction temperature has a great influence on the structure of the complexes. The magnetic behaviors and second harmonic generation activity of the complexes are reported.

elements.content: Over the past few decades, the chemistry of transition metal carboxylate system has been a rapidly expanding research field due to their fascinating structural diversities and potential applications as functional materials, and particularly the inorganic–organic hybrids with paramagnetic manganese(II) and carboxylate are of great interest driven by not only their potential as model compounds of the active sites of the metalloenzymes in the bioinorganic chemistry but also their promising application in the field of molecular magnetism. Among the reported works of metal carboxylate hybrids, various carboxylic acids have been used, for example, aliphatic, aromatic, and heterocyclic acids. We focus our attention on the study of the inorganic–organic hybrids with imidazole- or pyridine-containing N-donors as well as carboxylate ligands and have obtained various hybrids with interesting structures and properties. In the present study, a multifunctional organic ligand, 4,4′-bipyridine-2,2′,6,6′-tetracarboxylic acid (H4BPTCA), with N- and O-donor atoms synchronously was employed to react with manganese(II) salt, and herein three new Mn(II) carboxylate hybrids formulated as [Mn2(BPTCA)(phen)2·H2O] n (1), [Mn4(BPTCA)2(H2O)10·2.5H2O] n (2), and [Mn2(BPTCA)(μ 2 -H2O)2] n (3) are reported. In contrast to the well-studied organic ligands such as pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate and benzene di-, tri-, or tetracarboxylate, the H4BPTCA remains largely unexplored til now. In this paper, we present the synthesis, structures, and nonlinear optical and magnetic properties of the Mn(II)-BPTCA hybrids.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past few decades, the chemistry of transition metal carboxylate system has been a rapidly expanding research field due to their fascinating structural diversities and potential applications as functional materials, and particularly the inorganic-organic hybrids with paramagnetic manganese(II) and carboxylate are of great interest driven by not only their potential as model compounds of the active sites of the metalloenzymes in the bioinorganic chemistry but also their promising application in the field of molecular magnetism. Among the reported works of metal carboxylate hybrids, various carboxylic acids have been used, for example, aliphatic, aromatic, and heterocyclic acids. We focus our attention on the study of the inorganic-organic hybrids with imidazole- or pyridine-containing N-donors as well as carboxylate ligands and have obtained various hybrids with interesting structures and properties. In the present study, a multifunctional organic ligand, 4,4'-bipyridine-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4BPTCA), with N- and O-donor atoms synchronously was employed to react with manganese(II) salt, and herein three new Mn(II) carboxylate hybrids formulated as [Mn2(BPTCA)(phen)2⋅H2O] n  (1), [Mn4(BPTCA)2(H2O)10⋅2.5H2O] n  (2), and [Mn2(BPTCA)(μ 2 -H2O)2] n  (3) are reported. In contrast to the well-studied organic ligands such as pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylate and benzene di-, tri-, or tetracarboxylate, the H4BPTCA remains largely unexplored til now. In this paper, we present the synthesis, structures, and nonlinear optical and magnetic properties of the Mn(II)-BPTCA hybrids.

elements.content: All commercially available solvents and starting materials were used as received without further purification. The H4BPTCA ligand was prepared by the method reported in the literature. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Elemental analyses were taken on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Measurements of second harmonic generation (SHG) response: the second-order nonlinear optical intensity was estimated by measuring a powder sample 80–150 μm in diameter in the form of a pellet relative to urea. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate a SHG signal from powder samples. The backscattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation. The magnetic susceptibilities in the temperature range of 1.8 to 300 K were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS7 SQUID magnetometer in a field of 2 kOe. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal’s constants for all samples.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All commercially available solvents and starting materials were used as received without further purification. The H4BPTCA ligand was prepared by the method reported in the literature. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Elemental analyses were taken on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Measurements of second harmonic generation (SHG) response: the second-order nonlinear optical intensity was estimated by measuring a powder sample 80-150 μm in diameter in the form of a pellet relative to urea. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate a SHG signal from powder samples. The backscattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation. The magnetic susceptibilities in the temperature range of 1.8 to 300 K were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS7 SQUID magnetometer in a field of 2 kOe. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal's constants for all samples.

elements.content: A mixture of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O (49.5 mg, 0.2 mmol), H4BPTCA (33.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), phen (39.8 mg, 0.2 mmol), and NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.4 mmol) in H2O (8 mL) and C2H5OH (2 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 150 °C for 3 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, yellow block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol for several times with a yield of 74%. Anal. Calcd. for C38H22N6O9Mn2: C, 55.90; H, 2.72; N, 10.29%. Found: C, 55.89; H, 2.77; N, 10.20%. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, yellow block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol for several times with a yield of 74%. Anal. Calcd. for C38H22N6O9Mn2: C, 55.90; H, 2.72; N, 10.29%. Found: C, 55.89; H, 2.77; N, 10.20%. elements.content: The complex was prepared hydrothermally in a 20 mL Teflon lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of MnCl2·4H2O (40.8 mg, 0.2 mmol), H4BPTCA (33.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.4 mmol), and H2O (12 mL) at 150 °C for 3 days. Yellow-green block crystals of 2 were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol for several times with a yield of 45%. Anal. Calcd. for C28H33N4O28.5Mn4: C, 30.54; H, 3.02; N, 5.09%. Found: C, 30.68; H, 2.97; N, 5.34%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3406 (s, br), 1623 (vs), 1600 (vs), 1436 (s), 1385 (s), 1338 (s), 1248 (w), 1197 (w), 803 (w), 742 (w), 726 (m), 664 (m).

elements.content: Crystallographic data of 1−3 were collected at 20 °C on a Bruker SMART CCD system equipped with monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 71073 Å) using the ω – φ scan technique. The data integration and empirical absorption corrections were carried out by SAINT programs. The structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXS 97). All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques (SHELXL 97). All the hydrogen atoms except for those of the uncoordinated water molecules in 2 were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. Details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for 1−3 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1−3 are listed in Table . Further details are provided in the .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Crystallographic data of 1-3 were collected at 20 °C on a Bruker SMART CCD system equipped with monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 71073 Å) using the ω - φ scan technique. The data integration and empirical absorption corrections were carried out by SAINT programs. The structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXS 97). All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques (SHELXL 97). All the hydrogen atoms except for those of the uncoordinated water molecules in 2 were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. Details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for 1-3 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1-3 are listed in Table . Further details are provided in the .

It is known that the hydrothermal reaction is powerful synthetic technique resulting in new inorganic–organic hybrids with interesting structures; however, the reaction is affected by several factors such as reaction temperature and time. In this study, complex 1 was prepared with addition of phen as an ancillary ligand, while 2 and 3 with different structures were obtained under different reaction temperatures. Taking account of the decreasing dielectric constant and the polarity of water at high temperature of hydrothermal reaction that may favor more coordination from organic ligand via the elimination of coordinated water, the hydrothermal reactions for preparation of 2 and 3 were carried out at 150 and 180 °C, respectively. It is interesting that 2 is a two-dimensional (2D) chiral network with more water molecules coordinated to Mn(II), while 3 is a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework consisting of BPTCA4− anions and MnO6N polyhedral units with less coordinated water molecules (vide infra). The results provide a nice example of study on the role of the hydrothermal reaction temperature on the structure of the complexes. In addition, all carboxyl groups of the H4BPTCA ligand are deprotonated in 1−3, in good agreement with the IR spectral data since no strong bands around 1700 cm−1 for -COOH were observed in the synthesized complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation of the Complexes

It is known that the hydrothermal reaction is powerful synthetic technique resulting in new inorganic-organic hybrids with interesting structures; however, the reaction is affected by several factors such as reaction temperature and time. In this study, complex 1 was prepared with addition of phen as an ancillary ligand, while 2 and 3 with different structures were obtained under different reaction temperatures. Taking account of the decreasing dielectric constant and the polarity of water at high temperature of hydrothermal reaction that may favor more coordination from organic ligand via the elimination of coordinated water, the hydrothermal reactions for preparation of 2 and 3 were carried out at 150 and 180 °C, respectively. It is interesting that 2 is a two-dimensional (2D) chiral network with more water molecules coordinated to Mn(II), while 3 is a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework consisting of BPTCA4- anions and MnO6N polyhedral units with less coordinated water molecules (vide infra). The results provide a nice example of study on the role of the hydrothermal reaction temperature on the structure of the complexes. In addition, all carboxyl groups of the H4BPTCA ligand are deprotonated in 1-3, in good agreement with the IR spectral data since no strong bands around 1700 cm-1 for -COOH were observed in the synthesized complexes.

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction study revealed that each asymmetric unit of 1 contains one crystallographically unique Mn(II) ion coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of phen, one pyridyl nitrogen, and four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three different BPTCA4− ligands (Figure a), thereby forming a seven-coordinated structure with a N3O4 donor set. The Mn−O bond lengths are in the range of 2.1456(15)−2.3700(15) Å and Mn−N bond lengths are from 2.2178(18) to 2.362(2) Å (Table ), which are consistent with the reported seven-coordinated Mn(II) complexes. On the other hand, each side of BPTCA4− acts as a μ3-bridge to link three metal atoms, and each two carboxyl group has different coordination modes as exhibited in Scheme a: one acts as a antianti μ2-η1:η1 bridge through O3 and O4 atoms to connect two metal atoms with a Mn−Mn distance of 5.52 Å and the other one adopts a μ2-η2:η0-bridging mode using O2 to bridge two metal atoms with a Mn−Mn separation of 3.63 Å. Thus, the Mn(II) atoms in 1 are linked together by oxygen and carboxylate bridges to form an infinite O−Mn−O−C−O−Mn- one-dimensional (1D) chain (Figure b). The 2D network structure of 1 is achieved by the carboxylate groups on two sides of the BPTCA4− ligands coordinating to two adjacent 1D chains (Figure c).

The Mn-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.1456(15)-2.3700(15) Å and Mn-N bond lengths are from 2.2178(18) to 2.362(2) Å (Table ), which are consistent with the reported seven-coordinated Mn(II) complexes. On the other hand, each side of BPTCA4- acts as a μ3-bridge to link three metal atoms, and each two carboxyl group has different coordination modes as exhibited in Scheme a: one acts as a antianti μ2-η1:η1 bridge through O3 and O4 atoms to connect two metal atoms with a Mn-Mn distance of 5.52 Å and the other one adopts a μ2-η2:η0-bridging mode using O2 to bridge two metal atoms with a Mn-Mn separation of 3.63 Å. elements.content: Complex 2 was obtained by the reaction of H4BPTCA with MnCl2·4H2O without addition of an ancillary ligand. The crystallographic analysis showed that 2 crystallizes in a chiral space group P21, and there are 4 independent Mn(II) atoms, 2 BPTCA4−, 10 coordinated and 3 uncoordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit. As illustrated in Figure a, the four Mn(II) atoms are linked together by the carboxylate oxygen atoms of the BPTCA4− ligands to generate a Mn4 cluster, in which the Mn1 and Mn2 are pentagonal bipyramidally coordinated, and each of them is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two distinct BPTCA4− ligands, one pyridyl nitrogen and two aqua ligands, while Mn3 and Mn4 are also pentagonal bipyramidally coordinated, the only difference in the coordination environments between Mn1 (or Mn2) and Mn3 (or Mn4) is that one oxygen atom of the carboxylate group in Mn1 or Mn2 is substituted by one water molecule in Mn3 or Mn4. On the other hand, two independent BPTCA4− ligands have two different kinds of coordination modes as shown in Scheme , panels b and c, respectively. Each side of BPTCA4− ligand A (Scheme b) acts as a μ3-bridge to link three metal atoms (Mn1, Mn4, Mn3 or Mn2, Mn3, Mn4) and one of the two carboxyl groups has a μ 2 -η2:η1 coordination mode, while the other one adopts a μ2-η2: η0-bridging mode. In the case of BPTCA4− ligand B shown in Scheme c, each side of the ligand coordinates with one Mn(II) atom and each carboxylate group serves as monodentate.

In addition, the rich O−H---O hydrogen bonds formed by the coordinated water and the solvent molecules link the 2D layers to the 3D structure ().

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 3 there are seven atoms, namely, one pyridyl nitrogen, four oxygen atoms from three different BPTCA4− ligands, and two water oxygen atoms, coordinated to the central Mn(II) with a pentagonal bipyramidally coordination geometry as illustrated in Figure a. It is noticeable that the water oxygen atoms act as a bridge in 3 to link two metal atoms with a Mn−Mn distance of 3.64 Å, while in the case of 2 all the coordinated water molecules serve as terminal ligands. The coordination mode of the BPTCA4− ligand in 3 is similar to that in 1. Each side of the BPTCA4− ligand also acts as a μ3-bridge to link three metal atoms, and there are two types of carboxyl groups (Scheme d): one acts as a syn-anti μ2-η1:η1 bridge to link two metal atoms with a Mn−Mn distance of 5.63 Å, which is shorter than that in 1 (vide supra), the other one adopts a μ2-η2:η0-bridging mode with a Mn−Mn distance of 3.77 Å.

elements.content: The results of the present study showed that there are diverse coordination modes for the BPTCA4− ligand which can be seen clearly in Scheme . In 1 and 3, each BPTCA4− ligand has μ2-η1:η1 bridging and μ2-η2:η0 coordination modes to coordinate with six metal atoms. The only difference in the coordination mode of the BPTCA4− ligand in 1 and 3 is the μ2-η1:η1 mode which is antianti μ2-bridging in 1 but syn-anti μ2-bridging in 3. However, there are two independent BPTCA4− ligands with different coordination modes in 2 one also links six metal atoms adopts μ2-η2:η0 and μ2-η2:η1 modes which is different from that in 1 and 3, while the other one connects two metal atoms and each carboxylate coordinates with Mn(II) in monodentate mode.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of the Structures

The results of the present study showed that there are diverse coordination modes for the BPTCA4- ligand which can be seen clearly in Scheme . In 1 and 3, each BPTCA4- ligand has μ2-η1:η1 bridging and μ2-η2:η0 coordination modes to coordinate with six metal atoms. The only difference in the coordination mode of the BPTCA4- ligand in 1 and 3 is the μ2-η1:η1 mode which is antianti μ2-bridging in 1 but syn-anti μ2-bridging in 3. However, there are two independent BPTCA4- ligands with different coordination modes in 2 one also links six metal atoms adopts μ2-η2:η0 and μ2-η2:η1 modes which is different from that in 1 and 3, while the other one connects two metal atoms and each carboxylate coordinates with Mn(II) in monodentate mode.

elements.content: The remarkable difference between the structure of 2 and 3 implies the great influence of the hydrothermal reaction temperature. Changing the reaction temperature from 150 to 180 °C leads to the dimensionality variation from 2D in 2 to 3D in 3. Complex 2 has more coordinated water molecules in the structure, while in 3 the coordinated water molecules decreased greatly, and no solvent molecules were found just by increasing the reaction temperature (Scheme ). A similar phenomenon has been observed in the case of cobalt(II) succinate. The charge distributions in 1−3 are 0 (zero) for Mn(II) in 1; –1/2 for Mn1, Mn2 and 1/2 for Mn3, Mn4 in 2; 0 (zero) for Mn(II) in 3, implying that the reaction temperature also affects the charge distribution of the complexes as discussed by Bu et al.

elements.content: It is known that a noncentrosymmetric structure may have second-order nonlinear optic (NLO) effects, and due to the advantages over pure organic or inorganic compounds new NLO made up of organic–inorganic hybrid coordination polymers is especially interesting. Complex 2 crystallizes in the space group P21, which belongs to polar point group (C 2), so we performed quasi-Kurtz33 SHG measurements on a powder sample of 2 to confirm its acentricity as well as to evaluate its potential application as second-order NLO material. The preliminary result showed the bulk materials display modest powder SHG activity with a response of approximately 0.6 times of that for urea.
elements.clean_text:
Second-Harmonic-Generation Activity of 2 

It is known that a noncentrosymmetric structure may have second-order nonlinear optic (NLO) effects, and due to the advantages over pure organic or inorganic compounds new NLO made up of organic-inorganic hybrid coordination polymers is especially interesting. Complex 2 crystallizes in the space group P21, which belongs to polar point group (C 2), so we performed quasi-Kurtz33 SHG measurements on a powder sample of 2 to confirm its acentricity as well as to evaluate its potential application as second-order NLO material. The preliminary result showed the bulk materials display modest powder SHG activity with a response of approximately 0.6 times of that for urea.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured ranging from 1.8 to 300 K, and the result is shown in Figure a. The observed χM T value at 300 K is 8.228 emu K mol−1, which is near the value of 8.7 emu K mol−1 for two independent high-spin Mn(II) (g = 2) centers. The χM T value decreases slowly and then more rapidly below 50 K to reach a value of 0.360 emu K mol−1 at 1.8 K. A spin Hamiltonian H = −2JS 1 S 2 for two interacting S = 5 / 2 centers was used to fit the experimental data, where J is the coupling constant between neighboring metal ions. A good fit was achieved with the fitting parameters as follows: g = 1.98, J 1 = –1.17 cm−1, zj′ = –0.1449 cm−1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd − (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 3.73 × 10−3. The analysis confirms that the weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the Mn(II) atoms bridged by oxygen atoms is dominant while the exchange coupling through carboxylate bridge is expected to be very weak.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of the Complexes

The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured ranging from 1.8 to 300 K, and the result is shown in Figure a. The observed χM T value at 300 K is 8.228 emu K mol-1, which is near the value of 8.7 emu K mol-1 for two independent high-spin Mn(II) (g = 2) centers. The χM T value decreases slowly and then more rapidly below 50 K to reach a value of 0.360 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. A spin Hamiltonian H = -2JS 1 S 2 for two interacting S = 5 / 2  centers was used to fit the experimental data, where J is the coupling constant between neighboring metal ions. A good fit was achieved with the fitting parameters as follows: g = 1.98, J  1  = -1.17 cm-1, zj' = -0.1449 cm-1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd - (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 3.73 × 10-3. The analysis confirms that the weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the Mn(II) atoms bridged by oxygen atoms is dominant while the exchange coupling through carboxylate bridge is expected to be very weak.

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of 2 in the form of a χM T vs T plot is depicted in Figure b. The value of χM T is 17.80 emu K mol−1 at room temperature, which is quite close to the value of 17.5 emu K mol−1 for four independent high-spin Mn(II) (g = 2) centers. As the temperature decreases, the value of χM T decreases slowly and reaches 1.955 emu K mol−1 at 1.8 K. indicating the occurrence of dominant antiferromagnetic interactions within the Mn4 cluster. Complex 2 is, actually, a complicated 2D network made by tetranuclear Mn(II) clusters connected by the BPTCA4− ligands. It was assumed that there are two types exchange pathways in the tetranuclear cluster (inset of Figure b). Thus, the magnetic data above 8 K can be fitted assuming a quasi-isolated tetranuclear Mn(II) cluster with the Hamiltonian: H = –2J 1 S 1 S 2 – 2J 2(S 1 S 2′ + S 2 S 1 ). The best fit parameters are as follows: g = 2.04, J 1 = –1.299 cm−1, J 2 = –0.440 cm−1, zj′ = –0.0288 cm−1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd − (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 1.1 × 10−3.

The best fit parameters are as follows: g = 2.04, J 1 = -1.299 cm-1, J 2 = -0.440 cm-1, zj' = -0.0288 cm-1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd - (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 1.1 × 10-3.

elements.content: For complex 3, the room temperature χM T value is 4.16 emu K mol−1, which decreases steadily with decreasing temperature and tends to be zero at very low temperatures (Figure c), indicating an overall antiferromagnetic behavior. We only take into account the isotropic part of the exchange interaction and the contribution of the zero-field splitting was neglected. Magnetically, 3 is a uniform chain, in which there is only one type of superexchange pathway: the double μ 2 -O bridge. The interchain magnetic interactions through carboxyl bridge should be much weaker. The magnetic interaction within the chain can be fitted to the isotropic Hamiltonian H = –2JΣS i S i+1. We used the analytical expression derived by Fisher for a one-dimensional Heisenberg chain of classical spins [S = 5/2]. The best least-squares fit of the theoretical equation to experimental data leads to g = 1.979, J = –0.973 cm−1, zj′ = –0.059 cm−1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd − (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 3.73 × 10−3.

elements.content: The results of density functional theory (DFT) studies on Mn–(OR)2–Mn systems indicate dominant weak antiferromagnetic coupling as a function of the Mn–O–Mn bond angle below 98°, but there are reported antiferromagnetic interactions for Mn–O–Mn bond angles in the range of 98−110°. In our case, it is interesting to find that antiferromagnetic coupling occurred in the Mn–O–Mn bond angles of 112° in 2 and 147°, 148° in 3.

In our case, it is interesting to find that antiferromagnetic coupling occurred in the Mn-O-Mn bond angles of 112° in 2 and 147°, 148° in 3.

elements.content: Three inorganic–organic hybrids of Mn(II) were synthesized under hydrothermol conditions by using an interesting grid ligand 4,4′-bipyridine-2,2′,6,6′-tetracarboxylic acid. The different structures of the complexes are caused by the presence of an ancillary ligand, and different reaction temperatures. The results demonstrate that the reaction conditions have a great influence on the structure of the hybrids in this system, and as a consequence on the property of the complexes. The magnetic interactions between the Mn(II) centers occurred through infinite O−Mn−O−C−O-Mn- chains, Mn4 cluster, and Mn−O- chains in complexes 1, 2, and 3 respectively. Furthermore, compound 2 showed powder SHG activity and can be a multifunctional inorganic–organic hybrid material.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three inorganic-organic hybrids of Mn(II) were synthesized under hydrothermol conditions by using an interesting grid ligand 4,4'-bipyridine-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid. The different structures of the complexes are caused by the presence of an ancillary ligand, and different reaction temperatures. The results demonstrate that the reaction conditions have a great influence on the structure of the hybrids in this system, and as a consequence on the property of the complexes. The magnetic interactions between the Mn(II) centers occurred through infinite O-Mn-O-C-O-Mn- chains, Mn4 cluster, and Mn-O- chains in complexes 1, 2, and 3 respectively. Furthermore, compound 2 showed powder SHG activity and can be a multifunctional inorganic-organic hybrid material.

A mixture of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O (49.5 mg, 0.2 mmol), H4BPTCA (33.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), phen (39.8 mg, 0.2 mmol), and NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.4 mmol) in H2O (8 mL) and C2H5OH (2 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 150 °C for 3 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, yellow block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol for several times with a yield of 74%. Anal. Calcd. for C38H22N6O9Mn2: C, 55.90; H, 2.72; N, 10.29%. Found: C, 55.89; H, 2.77; N, 10.20%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3500 (m), 3456 (m), 3074 (w), 1676 (s), 1645 (vs),1597 (vs), 1515 (w), 1439 (w), 1423 (m), 1381 (s), 1327 (s), 1194 (w), 1083 (w), 842 (m), 735 (m), 726 (m), 687 (m).

Synthesis of [Mn<sub>4</sub>(BPTCA)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>10</sub>·2.5H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

The complex was prepared hydrothermally in a 20 mL Teflon lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of MnCl2·4H2O (40.8 mg, 0.2 mmol), H4BPTCA (33.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.4 mmol), and H2O (12 mL) at 150 °C for 3 days. cln_elements.content:
The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured ranging from 1.8 to 300 K, and the result is shown in Figure a. The observed χM T value at 300 K is 8.228 emu K mol−1, which is near the value of 8.7 emu K mol−1 for two independent high-spin Mn(II) (g = 2) centers. The χM T value decreases slowly and then more rapidly below 50 K to reach a value of 0.360 emu K mol−1 at 1.8 K. A spin Hamiltonian H = −2JS 1 S 2 for two interacting S = 5 / 2 centers was used to fit the experimental data, where J is the coupling constant between neighboring metal ions. A good fit was achieved with the fitting parameters as follows: g = 1.98, J 1 = –1.17 cm−1, zj′ = –0.1449 cm−1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd − (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 3.73 × 10−3. The analysis confirms that the weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the Mn(II) atoms bridged by oxygen atoms is dominant while the exchange coupling through carboxylate bridge is expected to be very weak.

The magnetic behavior of 2 in the form of a χM T vs T plot is depicted in Figure b. The value of χM T is 17.80 emu K mol−1 at room temperature, which is quite close to the value of 17.5 emu K mol−1 for four independent high-spin Mn(II) (g = 2) centers. As the temperature decreases, the value of χM T decreases slowly and reaches 1.955 emu K mol−1 at 1.8 K. indicating the occurrence of dominant antiferromagnetic interactions within the Mn4 cluster. Complex 2 is, actually, a complicated 2D network made by tetranuclear Mn(II) clusters connected by the BPTCA4− ligands. It was assumed that there are two types exchange pathways in the tetranuclear cluster (inset of Figure b). Thus, the magnetic data above 8 K can be fitted assuming a quasi-isolated tetranuclear Mn(II) cluster with the Hamiltonian: H = –2J 1 S 1 S 2 – 2J 2(S 1 S 2′ + S 2 S 1 ). The best fit parameters are as follows: g = 2.04, J 1 = –1.299 cm−1, J 2 = –0.440 cm−1, zj′ = –0.0288 cm−1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd − (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 1.1 × 10−3.

For complex 3, the room temperature χM T value is 4.16 emu K mol−1, which decreases steadily with decreasing temperature and tends to be zero at very low temperatures (Figure c), indicating an overall antiferromagnetic behavior. We only take into account the isotropic part of the exchange interaction and the contribution of the zero-field splitting was neglected. Magnetically, 3 is a uniform chain, in which there is only one type of superexchange pathway: the double μ 2 -O bridge. The interchain magnetic interactions through carboxyl bridge should be much weaker. The magnetic interaction within the chain can be fitted to the isotropic Hamiltonian H = –2JΣS i S i+1. We used the analytical expression derived by Fisher for a one-dimensional Heisenberg chain of classical spins [S = 5/2]. The best least-squares fit of the theoretical equation to experimental data leads to g = 1.979, J = –0.973 cm−1, zj′ = –0.059 cm−1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd − (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 3.73 × 10−3.

Magnetic Properties of the Complexes

The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured ranging from 1.8 to 300 K, and the result is shown in Figure a. The observed χM T value at 300 K is 8.228 emu K mol-1, which is near the value of 8.7 emu K mol-1 for two independent high-spin Mn(II) (g = 2) centers. The χM T value decreases slowly and then more rapidly below 50 K to reach a value of 0.360 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. A spin Hamiltonian H = -2JS 1 S 2 for two interacting S = 5 / 2  centers was used to fit the experimental data, where J is the coupling constant between neighboring metal ions. A good fit was achieved with the fitting parameters as follows: g = 1.98, J  1  = -1.17 cm-1, zj' = -0.1449 cm-1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd - (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 3.73 × 10-3. The analysis confirms that the weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the Mn(II) atoms bridged by oxygen atoms is dominant while the exchange coupling through carboxylate bridge is expected to be very weak.

The magnetic behavior of 2 in the form of a χM T vs T plot is depicted in Figure b. The value of χM T is 17.80 emu K mol-1 at room temperature, which is quite close to the value of 17.5 emu K mol-1 for four independent high-spin Mn(II) (g = 2) centers. As the temperature decreases, the value of χM T decreases slowly and reaches 1.955 emu K mol-1 at 1.8 K. indicating the occurrence of dominant antiferromagnetic interactions within the Mn4 cluster. Complex 2 is, actually, a complicated 2D network made by tetranuclear Mn(II) clusters connected by the BPTCA4- ligands. It was assumed that there are two types exchange pathways in the tetranuclear cluster (inset of Figure b). Thus, the magnetic data above 8 K can be fitted assuming a quasi-isolated tetranuclear Mn(II) cluster with the Hamiltonian: H = -2J 1 S 1 S 2 - 2J 2(S 1 S 2' + S 2 S  1 ). The best fit parameters are as follows: g = 2.04, J 1 = -1.299 cm-1, J 2 = -0.440 cm-1, zj' = -0.0288 cm-1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd - (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 1.1 × 10-3.

For complex 3, the room temperature χM T value is 4.16 emu K mol-1, which decreases steadily with decreasing temperature and tends to be zero at very low temperatures (Figure c), indicating an overall antiferromagnetic behavior. We only take into account the isotropic part of the exchange interaction and the contribution of the zero-field splitting was neglected. Magnetically, 3 is a uniform chain, in which there is only one type of superexchange pathway: the double μ 2 -O bridge. The interchain magnetic interactions through carboxyl bridge should be much weaker. The magnetic interaction within the chain can be fitted to the isotropic Hamiltonian H = -2JΣS  i  S  i+1. We used the analytical expression derived by Fisher for a one-dimensional Heisenberg chain of classical spins [S = 5/2]. The best least-squares fit of the theoretical equation to experimental data leads to g = 1.979, J = -0.973 cm-1, zj' = -0.059 cm-1 and the agreement factor R = Σ[(χM T)obsd - (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd is 3.73 × 10-3.

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Mn(II) in 1 with the ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level; hydrogen atoms and uncoordinated water molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) Infinite O−Mn−O−C−O-Mn- chain. (c) Polyhedral representation of the 2D network constructed by O−Mn−O−C−O-Mn- chains and BPTCA4− ligands. The uncoordinated water molecules and hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. (d) Slide fastener-like 3D structure of 1.
